questions.text: A newborn found to have clitoral enlargement and some degree of labial fusion. What is the next step in arriving at a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
When a newborn presents with ambiguous genitalia, the primary concern is to determine the chromosomal, gonadal, and anatomical sex of the child, which will guide further diagnostic and therapeutic steps. Karyotyping will help differentiate between 46,XX and 46,XY disorders of sex development (DSD).

The presentation you provided does raise the suspicion of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), particularly in a 46,XX individual, but it's crucial to first identify the chromosomal sex of the baby.

In the case of a newborn with ambiguous genitalia, with 46XX karyotype, the most like diagnosis is CAH-congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). The most common form, accounting for about 95% of cases, is 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

The initial screening test for 21-hydroxylase deficiency is the measurement of serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17OH progesterone) levels. Elevated levels are suggestive of the condition, and further confirmatory tests can then be pursued.

questions.text: In Figure A, a specific complication associated with monochorionic twins is depicted. Should this condition be diagnosed prior to the 26th week of gestation, what is the most optimal therapeutic intervention that can be recommended?
questions.solution:
Twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) is a serious complication that can occur in monochorionic twin pregnancies. It arises due to abnormal vascular connections between the twins in the shared placenta. One twin (the donor) may become volume-depleted and oliguric, leading to oligohydramnios, while the other twin (the recipient) becomes volume-overloaded, leading to polyuria and polyhydramnios.

When TTTS is diagnosed prior to the 26th week of gestation, the most optimal therapeutic intervention is Laser photocoagulation of the placental anastomoses.

During this procedure, the surgeon will use a fetoscope to visualize the placental surface and then coagulate the abnormal vascular connections between the twins with a laser. The aim is to halt the pathological flow of blood between the twins, thus resolving the syndrome.

It's important to note that early diagnosis and intervention can greatly improve outcomes, as untreated TTTS has a high morbidity and mortality rate.

questions.text: A 38-year-old expectant mother attends an antenatal care (ANC) clinic, presenting with results from her 20-week anomaly scan. The ultrasound report indicates an abnormal increase in amniotic fluid. Based on the accompanying ultrasound image provided, what might be the probable etiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
The "double bubble sign" on a prenatal ultrasound is a classic indicator of duodenal atresia. In the context of this ultrasound finding, the two "bubbles" represent the dilated stomach and proximal duodenum, which are separated by the atretic segment.

Etiology:

Duodenal atresia is a congenital anomaly where there is a blockage of the duodenum, preventing the passage of stomach contents into the distal intestines.

ASSOCIATION WITH DOWNS SYNDROME-

A significant number of babies with duodenal atresia also have Down syndrome, so it's often recommended to perform further investigations like karyotyping when duodenal atresia is identified on ultrasound.

questions.text: MC congenital abnormality of uterus is:

Ms. XY is 64 years old and is postmenopausal. She has recently been diagnosed with a 4 cm ovarian cyst on a transabdominal scan. The scan could not identify the other ovary as the bowel obscured it. The scan was being undertaken for suspected gallstones with the cyst being an incidental finding. Ms. XY is very anxious that this may represent ovarian cancer. Which of the following investigations are best suited to her to further investigate the ovarian cyst?
questions.solution:
Here's why:

Transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS) is the primary imaging modality for assessing adnexal masses. It can help evaluate the characteristics of the cyst (simple vs. complex, solid components, septations, vascularity) and provide information on the likelihood of malignancy.

CA-125 is a blood test that measures the level of cancer antigen 125 in the blood. Elevated levels of CA-125 can be indicative of ovarian cancer, but it's worth noting that CA-125 can be elevated in many other conditions as well (including endometriosis, fibroids, and pelvic inflammatory disease).

The Risk of Malignancy Index (RMI) is a scoring system used to evaluate the likelihood that an ovarian cyst or mass is malignant. The RMI is calculated using the ultrasound findings, menopausal status, and serum CA-125 level. A higher RMI score indicates a higher risk of malignancy.

While both CT Abdomen and Pelvis (Option B) and MRI (Option C) can further characterize the mass, they are generally not the first-line modalities for evaluation of an adnexal mass.

choices.text: Both male and female fetuses initially have both a Wolffian (mesonephric) duct that lies medially and a Müllerian (paramesonephric) duct that lies laterally.
Primordial germ cells form by week 8, subsequently migrating into the developing ovary at week 11 and differentiating into oogonia.
The paramesonephric duct develops into the uterus and fallopian tubes, while the vagina develops from the vaginal plate.
The two Müllerian ducts fuse at the caudal end to form the body of the developing uterus, and the unfused lateral arms form the fallopian tubes.

questions.text: During embryological development of the normal female reproductive system in humans, which of the following does not occur?
questions.solution:
Answer-The urogenital system develops from the intermediate mesothelium of the peritoneal cavity and the endoderm of the urogenital sinus. The ovaries are derived from the mesodermal epithelium lining of the posterior abdominal wall, and primordial germ cells form by week 4, subsequently migrating into the developing Gonadal ridge at week 6.

Both male and female fetuses initially have both a Wolffian (mesonephric) duct that lies medially and a Mullerian (paramesonephric) duct that lies laterally. The presence of a Y chromosome leads to male sex determination, and in its absence and in the presence of two X chromosomes, the Wolffian ducts regress due to a lack of testosterone and the Mullerian ducts persist due to the absence of Mullerian inhibitory factor.

The paramesonephric duct develops into the uterus and fallopian tubes, while the vagina develops from the vaginal plate. The two Mullerian ducts fuse at the caudal end to form the body of the developing uterus and the unfused lateral arms form the fallopian tubes. The fused caudal portion extends cranially, eventually developing a central cavity, leading to development of the functional uterus.

choices.text: Abandon the procedure now and discuss with her treatment for ectopic pregnancy later.
Do bilateral salpingectomy to prevent further ectopic pregnancies and plan fertility treatment later.
Remove the ectopic pregnancy at the same sitting and debrief her later.

questions.text: A 34-year-old nullipara is undergoing treatment for primary infertility. She has irregular periods with a cycle length varying from 45 to 60 days. Her last menstrual period was about 7 weeks back. She was posted for diagnostic hysterolaparoscopy, and the laparoscopic findings are given below. She is hemodynamically stable and the right fallopian tube appears healthy. You have taken consent only for diagnostic hysterolaparoscopy. What is the most appropriate course of action?
questions.solution:
A potentially viable pregnancy should not be terminated without the woman's consent. If a preg-nancy is discovered at the start of a hysterectomy, including one for cancer, the operation should be rescheduled. An unexpected ectopic pregnancy should be removed. It is reasonable to presume that the woman would wish this and would wish the surgeon to act in favour of life-saving treatment.

Ideally All reasonable steps should be taken to exclude pregnancy before embarking upon any surgical procedure

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, has undergone a hysterectomy due to a fibroid uterus. Based on the image provided below, which FIGO grade corresponds to the fibroid observed?
questions.solution: Answer -The image is showing a cervical fibroid.

questions.text: "Vault prolapse is a potential complication after vaginal hysterectomy. Which of the following surgical procedures is specifically employed during a vaginal hysterectomy to prevent this complication?
questions.solution:
McCall culdoplasty

During McCall culdoplasty, the uterosacral ligaments are sutured together in the midline behind the vaginal vault. This not only obliterates the cul-de-sac but also provides support to the vaginal vault, thereby reducing the risk of subsequent prolapse.

Of the above, McCall culdoplasty is the procedure most commonly employed during a vaginal hysterectomy specifically to prevent vault prolapse.

questions.text: Ms XY is 38 years old and suffers from primary infertility and dysmenorrhoea. Her recent TV scan is given below H She is due to undergo IVF. Which treatment is best suited in this condition?
questions.solution:
The figure shows an ovarian cyst with ground glass appearance suggestive of nedometriotic cyst.

Expectant management is often the first line of management, especially if:

  • The cyst is discovered incidentally (not due to symptoms but found during an evaluation for another reason).
  • The woman is not experiencing any pain or other symptoms attributable to the cyst.
  • There are no concerns based on the appearance or characteristics of the cyst on imaging.
  • The woman is not currently trying to conceive or doesn't have infertility concerns.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has been trying to conceive for 3 years. She has infrequent menstrual cycles. Her HSG and USG images are given below. Her partner's semen analysis is reported as within normal limits. Her BMI is 25 kg/m2. She has normal prolactin, FSH, oestradiol and testosterone. Of the options listed, which one of the following therapies is considered the most appropriate initial therapy?
questions.solution:
In the given image Usg is suggestive of polycystic ovary, HSG shows B/L spill.

The woman has infrequent menstrual cycles, suggesting ovulatory issues due to PCOD

The partner's semen analysis is normal.

Her BMI is 25 kg/m^2, which is within the normal range.

Hormonal studies, including prolactin, FSH, estradiol, and testosterone, are normal.

Clomiphene citrate is an ovulation-inducing agent and they are used as first-line treatment for women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and other ovulatory disorders.

questions.text: A 29yr old female patient goes into labour. She has had an uneventful pregnancy. You are called in as the patient has fresh vaginal bleeding after rupture of membrane associated with fetal distress. In this condition, which of the following test is useful to differentiate maternal and fetal blood?
questions.solution:
This test is used to differentiate between fetal hemoglobin (HbF) and adult hemoglobin (HbA). Fetal hemoglobin is resistant to alkali denaturation, so when mixed with an alkali solution, HbF remains pink, while HbA turns brown or yellow. This can help determine if the blood is from the fetus (for instance, due to vasa previa) or the mother.

Kleihauer-Betke Test: This test is used to detect fetal red blood cells in the maternal circulation, often used in the setting of trauma or other events to determine the amount of fetal-maternal hemorrhage and guide Rh immune globulin administration in Rh-negative mothers.

questions.text: Patient X, 40Yr old female, found that after combined testing in first trimester, there was high risk of downs syndrome in baby. She has come to you at 16wk, asking for further management. What is the most appropriate test for her?
questions.solution:
The diagnostic test to confirm the presence or absence of Down's syndrome is: CVS and Amniocentesis.

Amniocentesis -It's typically performed between 15 and 20 weeks of gestation, making it the most appropriate choice for this patient at 16 weeks.

Triple marker, Quadruple marker: This is a screening test, not a diagnostic test.

choices.text: 20ml 20%, 5gm MGSO4 IM + 50% 5gm IM in each
10ml 10%, 4gm MGSO4 IM + 50% 5gm IM in each
20ml 20%, 4gm MGSO4 IM + 50% 5gm IM in each
20ml 20% 4gm, MGSO4 IM + 50% 5gm IM in buttock

questions.text: What is the loading dose of MgS04 used for eclampsia?
questions.solution:
The Pritchard regimen is a widely recognized protocol for the administration of magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) for the prevention and treatment of eclampsia and severe preeclampsia in pregnant women.

In the Pritchard regimen, the loading dose of magnesium sulfate consists of:

  • Intramuscular (IM) administration: 5 grams of 50% magnesium sulfate solution given in the upper outer quadrant of each buttock, totaling 10 grams.
  • Intravenous (IV) administration: Simultaneously with the IM injection, 4 grams of 20% magnesium sulfate solution is given slowly over 5 minutes.

So, the total initial loading dose is 14 grams.

choices.text: Early deceleration is seen in placental insufficiency
Late Deceleration is associated cord compression
Variable deceleration has an abrupt fall in heart rate 15bpm below baseline

questions.text: Which among the following is true?
questions.solution:
• Early decelerations are typically associated with head compression (specifically, fetal head descent and compression against the cervix during a contraction).
  • Late decelerations are indicative of placental insufficiency or uteroplacental insufficiency, which means the fetus is not getting enough oxygen during contractions.
  • Variable decelerations are typically associated with umbilical cord compression.

questions.text: Identify the degree of tear that is shown below
questions.solution:
3rd-degree perineal tear:

This tear involves the vaginal tissue, perineal muscles, and extends through the anal sphincter complex. It can be further categorized into:

  • 3a: Involves less than 50% of the external anal sphincter.
  • 3b: Involves more than 50% of the external anal sphincter.
  • 3c: Involves both the external and internal anal sphincters.

In this anal mucosa is not involved.

choices.text: Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh

questions.text: While operating on a patient in lithotomy position, the padding between the lateral fibular heads and the stirrup prevents injury to:
questions.solution: Common peroneal nerve. When a patient is in the lithotomy position, the common peroneal nerve is vulnerable as it wraps around the head of the fibula. Pressure against the lateral fibular head can cause injury to this nerve. Padding is used to prevent such injury.

questions.text: Identify the forceps which is shown below
questions.solution:
Piper's forceps are obstetric forceps designed specifically for use in breech deliveries, especially for extracting the after-coming head of a breech baby.

The characteristic identification features of Piper's forceps-

  1. They have a significant posterior curve, which aligns with the curvature of the maternal pelvis and the fetal head during a breech delivery.
  2. Unlike many other obstetric forceps, the blades of Piper's forceps are relatively short.
  3. The handles are angled sharply upward, allowing the obstetrician to apply traction in the appropriate direction for a breech extraction.
  4. Unlike the standard obstetric forceps which have crossing shanks, the shanks of Piper's forceps do not cross over each other. This design aids in avoiding pressure on the fetal neck.

questions.text: A 46-year-old female suffering from severe menorrhagia underwent hysterectomy. She wishes to take hormone replacement therapy. Physical examination and breast are normal but X-ray shows osteoporosis. The treatment of choice is:
questions.solution:
• The female underwent hysterectomy, i.e. surgical menopause at the age of 48 years and her X-ray shows osteoporosis - hence HRT can be advised.
  • Both estrogen alone or estrogen + progesterone can be used for treating osteoporosis. The choice depends on whether the uterus is present or not (i.e. patient is hysterectomised or not).

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a self-retaining retractor?
questions.solution: The Balfour retractor is an example of a self-retaining retractor. It's often used in abdominal surgeries to hold open the incision, allowing the surgeon to work more easily within the abdomen without the need for an assistant to hold the retractor in place.

questions.text: All the following are neonatal complication see in infant of a diabetic mother except
questions.solution: Infants of diabetic mothers (IDMs) are at risk for several complications. Among the options provided Hypobilirubinemia is NOT a complication seen in infants of diabetic mothers. In fact, they are at risk for hyperbilirubinemia (increased bilirubin levels), not reduced bilirubin levels.

questions.text: Based on the placental anomaly depicted in the image, which of the following is NOT a recognized complication of a circumvallate placenta?
questions.solution: Among the options provided PPH is NOT a complication seen in circumvallate placenta. PPH is more common with placental anomalies such as succenturiate lobe of placenta

questions.text: A 25yr old patient who is 28wk POG, presents to review her Antenatal liver function test which was taken last week. Patient says that she was itchy when the blood test was taken , but it seems to have settled . SGOT-25, SGPT- 20, aLbumin-3.6gm/dl, ALP- 205U/L. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
As the patient's symptoms have settled and there's no significant derangement in the liver function tests , monitoring without further immediate testing can be considered.

However, it's essential for the patient to be informed about the symptoms and to report immediately if itching or any other concerning symptoms recur. Regular antenatal monitoring would still be important

questions.text: A 27yr old female at 9wk POG, with vaginal bleeding. She advices she has terrible morning sickness. Examination reveals a 14wk size uterus. Her USG images regimen below. What is the idea treatment of choice in this situation?
questions.solution: The "snowstorm" appearance on imaging is indicative of a molar pregnancy, a form of gestational trophoblastic disease. Definitive management involves suction evacuation to remove the molar tissue. Post-procedure, it's crucial to monitor beta-HCG levels regularly to ensure complete removal and detect any potential malignant transformation

questions.text: A patient comes for ANC checkup in first trimester, her HB-11gm/dl, FBS-150mg/dl, PPBS- 240. How will you manage her?
questions.solution: A fasting blood sugar level exceeding 126 mg/dl and a postprandial (PP) value surpassing 200 mg/dl indicate overt diabetes. While dietary modifications and medical nutrition therapy (MNT) play essential roles in management, insulin is the cornerstone of treatment. Ensuring appropriate insulin therapy is fundamental to achieving optimal blood sugar control in these patients.

questions.text: The role of the sentinel lymph node mapping is most established in this gynaecological malignancy:
questions.solution:
The role of sentinel lymph node mapping is most established in Vulval cancer.

Sentinel lymph node biopsy has become an integral part of the management of early-stage vulvar cancer to determine lymph node involvement without the need for more extensive and potentially morbid surgical procedures.

questions.text: Based on the histological pattern depicted in the provided image, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Call-Exner bodies are small eosinophilic fluid-filled spaces between granulosa cells.

They are usually associated with granulosa cell tumour. The micro-follicular variant, the most easily recognised, is characterised by multiple small rounded spaces formed by cystic degeneration in small aggregates of granulosa cells, containing eosinophilic PAS-positive material (chondroitin 6-sulphate) and often fragments of nuclear debris or pyknotic nuclei.

choices.text: The karyotype in this condition is 46XY
It is inherited as Y-linked trait
There is insensitivity to androgens secreted by the testis

questions.text: With regards to complete androgen insensitivity syndrome:
questions.solution:
A) The karyotype in this condition is 46XY - True. Individuals with CAIS have a male (46XY) karyotype, but their external appearance is typically female because their bodies do not respond to androgens.

B) The breast development is normal - True. Due to the body's inability to respond to androgens, the default pathway is the female developmental pattern. This includes typical breast development in puberty, often driven by the conversion of androgens into estrogens.

C) It is inherited as a Y-linked trait - False. CAIS is an X-linked recessive disorder. It is caused by mutations in the AR gene located on the X chromosome.

D) There is insensitivity to androgens secreted by the testis - True. CAIS results from a mutation in the androgen receptor gene, making tissues unresponsive to androgens, including those produced by the testes.

questions.text: All of the following take part in male genital tract development except:
questions.solution:
WNT-4

does NOT take part in male genital tract development. WNT-4 is associated with female development and acts to suppress the male pathway. In the absence of WNT-4 (and the presence of SRY on the Y chromosome), the gonad will differentiate into a testis.

questions.text: Muscles at perineal body:
questions.solution:
The perineal body is a fibromuscular node at the center of the perineum and serves as a major attachment point for several muscles.T

(A) Levator ani

(B) Superficial and deep transverse perinei

(C) External anal sphincter

All of these muscles insert, at least in part, into the perineal body.

choices.text: One side steak and other dysgenetic gonads

questions.text: About Pure gonadal dysgenesis, what is true?
questions.solution:
• Pure gonadal dysgenesis refers to 46, XX or 46, XY phenotypic females who have streak gonads
  • Sporadically or may be inherited as an autosomal recessive trait or as an X-linked trait in XY gonadal dysgenesis
  • Clinical features-
    • Phenotypic Females of average height with poor Secondary sexual character
    • No stigmata of turner syndrome.
    • Gonads are streak without any potential to produce hormone
    • The vagina, uterus, and tubes are present although infantile.
    • elevated levels of FSH
    • Primary amenorrhea
  • When gonadal dysgenesis occurs in 46,XY individuals, it is sometimes termed Swyer syndrome

questions.text: A 25 year old pregnant woman with a fibroid uterus develops acute pain in abdomen with low-grade fever and mild leukocytosis at 29 week. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, where a 25-year-old pregnant woman with a known fibroid presents with acute abdominal pain, low-grade fever, and mild leukocytosis at 29 weeks of gestation, the most likely diagnosis is Red degeneration of fibroid

Red degeneration, also known as carneous degeneration, often occurs in pregnancy due to the rapid growth of the fibroid and insufficient blood supply, leading to hemorrhagic infarction of the fibroid. This condition can cause severe pain, and the clinical picture is often associated with fever and leukocytosis.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old young girl presents in the casualty with acute pain in the lower abdomen. She has history of cyclical pain for the last 5 months and she has not attained her menarche yet. On local genital examination, a tense bulge in the region of hymen was seen.

The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Given the clinical presentation of a 12-year-old girl with cyclical pain, absence of menarche, and a tense bulge in the region of the hymen, the most likely diagnosis is. Imperforate hymen

An imperforate hymen prevents the normal outflow of menstrual blood, leading to its accumulation in the vagina (hematocolpos) and potentially further back into the uterus (hematometra). This can present as cyclical pain (corresponding with the menstrual cycle) and a bulging hymen due to the accumulation of menstrual blood behind it.

questions.text: Which form of progestogen-only contraception is most strongly associated with loss of bone mineral density?
questions.solution:
The progestogen-only contraceptive most strongly associated with a loss of bone mineral density is:

option A: Depo medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA)

Long-term use of DMPA has been linked to a reduction in bone mineral density, which tends to recover after discontinuation of the method. This potential side effect has led to recommendations that bone health should be considered when choosing DMPA, especially in adolescents and those with other risk factors for osteoporosis.

questions.text: What investigation is not indicated in recurrent first-trimester loss?
questions.solution:
Among the options provided for investigations in recurrent first-trimester loss:

Option D: TORCH screening

is generally not recommended as a routine investigation in the case of recurrent first-trimester pregnancy loss. The acronym TORCH stands for Toxoplasmosis, Other (syphilis, varicella-zoster, parvovirus B19), Rubella, Cytomegalovirus (CMV), and Herpes infections. While these infections can have implications during pregnancy, routine screening for them is not typically performed solely based on recurrent first-trimester losses.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman complains of intermenstrual bleeding for the past 6 months. Past history includes 6 normal vaginal deliveries and hypertension and last smear was over 5 years ago. On speculum examination, there is a raised 2 cm friable area on the cervix. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given the age of the woman, the duration of her symptoms, the physical findings of a raised 2 cm friable area on the cervix, and the history of a smear that was over 5 years ago, the most concerning and likely diagnosis is Cervical cancer

This presentation warrants immediate investigation, which may include a biopsy of the lesion. Regular cervical screening is essential to detect precancerous changes early, before they develop into cancer.

questions.text: An 84-year-old patient who had a previous history of vaginal hysterectomy presents with a stage 3 vault prolapse. The patient has limited mobility and has previously had difficulty with the use of vaginal pessaries. What is the most appropriate treatment option?
questions.solution:
Given the age of the patient (84 years old), her limited mobility, difficulty with pessary use, and a stage 3 vault prolapse, the most appropriate treatment option that offers a permanent solution without the necessity of a more invasive abdominal surgery would be Colpocleisis

Colpocleisis (or LeFort colpocleisis) involves the surgical closure of the vaginal vault, and it's often considered for elderly women who are no longer sexually active and have medical comorbidities that make them poor candidates for more extensive surgical procedures. This procedure has a high success rate with low morbidity.

choices.text: Wait and watch for progress of labour

questions.text: When inlayer the diagnosis of occiputoposterior presentation is made. The most appropriate management would be:
questions.solution:
In the context of an occiput posterior (OP) presentation during labor:

The occiput posterior position refers to a situation where the fetal occiput (back of the head) is positioned towards the mother's posterior, which can sometimes result in a more prolonged and painful labor due to the suboptimal fit of the fetal head in the maternal pelvis.

Given the provided options Wait and watch for progress of labour

questions.text: The following sign is seen in which of the following -
questions.solution:
The "lemon sign" is a fetal ultrasound finding in which the fetal head appears to be shaped like a lemon, often due to the scalloping of the frontal bone.

The presence of the lemon sign, especially in the second trimester, increases the risk of spina bifida,It is also seen in cases of chiari II malformation, a condition often associated with spina bifida.

questions.text: With oral iron, rise of Hb % can be seen after:
questions.solution: After starting oral iron supplementation, the rise in hemoglobin can typically be observed after 3week. And as per Anemia Mukt Bharath program testing is done after 1month(4weeks)
